hints_html:
Note that if two vertices of the rectangle must lie on the graph of the function \(\displaystyle y=8-x^2\), the two vertices on the x-axis must be equidistant from the origin.

Suppose that the base of the rectangle measures \(2b\) units long. What is an expression for the area of the rectangle, in terms of \(b\)?

If the base of the rectangle measures \(2b\), its bottom right vertex is located at \((b, 0)\). Therefore its top right vertex is located at \((b,8-b^2)\) and it follows that its dimensions are \(2b\) by \(8-b^2\). Hence its area is \(2b(8-b^2)\). How can we maximize the value of this expression?

hints_raw:
Note that if two vertices of the rectangle must lie on the graph of the function <math>\displaystyle y=8-x^2</math>, the two vertices on the x-axis must be equidistant from the origin.
Suppose that the base of the rectangle measures <math>2b</math> units long. What is an expression for the area of the rectangle, in terms of <math>b</math>?
If the base of the rectangle measures <math>2b</math>, its bottom right vertex is located at <math>(b, 0)</math>. Therefore its top right vertex is located at <math>(b,8-b^2)</math> and it follows that its dimensions are <math>2b</math> by <math>8-b^2</math>. Hence its area is <math>2b(8-b^2)</math>. How can we maximize the value of this expression?
sols_html:
If the base of the rectangle measures \(\displaystyle 2b\), its area is \(\displaystyle A(b) = 2b(8-b^2) = 16b - 2b^3\). To maximize \(\displaystyle A\), we find its critical points by finding \(\displaystyle A'\):

\[\begin{aligned} A(b) &= 16b - 2b^3 \\ A'(b) &= 16 - 6b^2 \\ \\ 0 &= 16 - 6b^2 \\ 6b^2 &= 16 \\ b &= \pm \sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\end{aligned}\]

A simple inspection shows that \(b = \sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\) is a maximum point of A since A’ changes sign from positive to negative at that point. The value of A(b) at that b (i.e., the maximum area) is:

\[\begin{aligned} A\left(\sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\right) &= 2\sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\left(8-\left(\sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}\right)^2\right) \\ &= { \color{blue} \frac{32}{3} \cdot \sqrt{\frac{8}{3}}} = { \color{blue} \frac{64\sqrt{2}}{3\sqrt{3}}} = { \color{blue} \frac{64\sqrt{6}}{9} }\end{aligned}\]
